newsitem.title: USA: FCC expected to reject Ameritech long-distance bid.
newsitem.headline: FCC expected to reject Ameritech long-distance bid.

text.p: Tuesday to reject Ameritech Corp.'s bid to become the first Baby Bell to enter the $80 billion long-distance phone business, government officials said Monday.
The Chicago-based carrier wants to offer long-distance dialing from its own calling region and has sought permission to provide the service to residents in Michigan.

But the Federal Communications Commission is set to conclude that Ameritech has not yet fully opened its local network in the state to new competitors -- such as long-distance carriers -- wanting to offer their own brand of local calling, the officials said.
Under last year's communications law, a regional Bell can offer long-distance dialing to local customers once it proves it has opened its local market to rivals.
Still, the expected FCC rejection should in the longer run prove valuable to Ameritech and its Bell rivals by offering a detailed road map on how to win FCC approval, analysts said.

"It's all about defining the goal posts for Bell entry. The whole process right now is extremely unclear," said analyst Scott Cleland of Legg Mason Precursor Group, the research arm of the Baltimore-based brokerage.

In June, the FCC rejected SBC Communications Inc.'s application to offer long-distance service in Oklahoma, saying the San Antonio, Texas-based Baby Bell had failed to meet the requirements of the 1996 telecommunications act.
But the FCC offered little guidance on what steps the Bells must take to pass regulatory muster, largely because the agency did not view SBC's application as a serious effort.

The Ameritech decision comes after FCC Chairman Reed Hundt last week complained that the landmark communications law was not working and that Congress should amend it to pry open the $100 billion local phone service market to competition.
Hundt noted that long-distance carriers and other new entrants to the local phone business have grabbed just 1 percent to 2 percent of the total market.

Ameritech was the first Bell at the start of the year to ask the FCC for permission to offer long-distance service. But the carrier was forced to yank its initial application because it was riddled with errors.
Ameritech has about 3.5 million customers in Michigan. The carrier values the long-distance market in its five-state territory in the Midwest at about $9 billion a year.
